ERSmeta Description: Name of the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Name of the resource

ERSmeta Description: Abbreviation of the software name.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: A short name (e.g., temperature) capturing the high-level concept of the variable

ERSmeta Description: The identifier property represents any kind of identifier for any kind of Thing, such as DOI, ISBNs, GTIN codes, UUIDs etc.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Identifier of the resource being described

ERSmeta Description: Link to the logo of the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Property that links to the image used as logo for a software component

ERSmeta Description: Version of the software instance as used by the developers.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: A software version is a specificf type of software that represents a particular set of functionalities. New functionalities and error fixes may occur between software versions

ERSmeta Description: The computer programming language in which the software is written.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Language used to code a software component

ERSmeta Description: Language used within the software (e.g. variables, documentation). Standard: IETF (BCP47)
A one-line summary of what the software does.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: A summarized description of the resource

ERSmeta Description: A description of the software. Max 200 words.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: A description of a resource

ERSmeta Description: Keywords or tags used to describe this software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Keywords associated with a software component

ERSmeta Description: Graphical overview on the functionality of the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Function to link a function with its corresponding container

ERSmeta Description: Research domain for which the software was written.
Research category for which the software was written.
Type of software application, e.g. 'script'.
Kind of tasks that the software tasks over in research.
Homepage of the tool. URL of the item.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Website of the software

ERSmeta Description: Description of development status, e.g. Active, inactive, suspended. See repostatus.org
Structure of the development team.
How often is the software updated?
Link to software bug reporting or issue tracking system
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Pointer to the issue tracker of a software component

ERSmeta Description: Any academic publication which describes the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Main publication to cite for this software component

ERSmeta Description: A reference to another work that should be cited instead of the software or dataset itself. Note that the principles of  software citation and data citation require that software should be cited on the same basis as any other research product such as a paper or a book. Adding a different preferred citation may result in a violation of the respective primary principle, Importance, when others cite this work.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: How to cite this software

ERSmeta Description: A license document that applies to this software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: License of a software component or its source code

ERSmeta Description: The party holding the legal copyright to the CreativeWork.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Copyright holder for a software component

ERSmeta Description: A flag to signal that the software is accessible for free.
Typical cost for licensing the software, if available.
The date on which the software was initially created.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Date when a software component was created

ERSmeta Description: The date on which the software was most recently modified.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Date when a software component was published

ERSmeta Description: A person who has contributed to the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Contributor to a software component

ERSmeta Description: A person who has authored the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: The creator of a software component

ERSmeta Description: Individual responsible for maintaining the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Contact person responsible for a software component

ERSmeta Description: Institution which developed the software.
Country where the software was developed. Country codes as defined by ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 should be used.
Information on the funding which was used to develop the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Property that links a software project to its funding information

ERSmeta Description: If the file can be downloaded, URL to download the binary.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Download URL where to obtain the source/executable of the software

ERSmeta Description: Link to the repository where the un-compiled, human readable code and related code is located (SVN, GitHub, CodePlex, institutional GitLab instance, etc.).
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: URL to the code repository of a software component

ERSmeta Description: Link to the documentation describing the code and is usful for developers.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Pointer to the documentation of the model

ERSmeta Description: Link to software readme file.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: URl to the readme file of a software component

ERSmeta Description: Link to installation instructions/documentation.
Is support for the software provided?
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Property to link details, such as mailing lists in case a contact person is not provided

ERSmeta Description: How long would a researcher need to be able to use the software?
Code examples for using the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: An example explaining a scenario where the software component was used in plain language.

ERSmeta Description: Ways how the software developers interact with the software users (community).
A publication which uses the software for its research.
Description of the output functions of the software (e.g., APIs)
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Property that expresses what are the outputs of a model

ERSmeta Description: Description of the input functions of the software (e.g., APIs)
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Property that links a model configuration to the input types expected by it.

ERSmeta Description: A software which can directly be used with the software without further changes.
Hardware which is compatible to this software (e.g., in labs).
Data which is compatible to this software.
Data that is directly used by the provided software
A general goal/purpose of the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Objective or main functionality that can be achieved by running this software

ERSmeta Description: An used method in the software.
A supported sector of the software. A sector is generically dependent continuant that is a subdivision of a system.
A supported energy technology of the software.
A required assumption of the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Assumptions of a software, e.g. the solver being used for a particular model, the source of the data (e.g., all data must have a given resolution), etc.

ERSmeta Description: Other supported use case, e.g., a research question which can be answered with the software besides the main goal.
A component of the energy system included in the software.
A limitation of the software.
A relevant internal parameter of the software.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Property that indicates the parameters of a model configuration

ERSmeta Description: A feature of the software.
Supported temporal resolution of the software. Temporal resolution is the resolution that indicates time-dependent the level of detail.
Time scope the software was developed for (e.g. 2010, 2050).
Does the software support stationary or transient effects?
Supported spatial resolution of the software. Spatial resolution is the resolution that indicates the geographical level of detail.
Supported dimensions of the software.
Geo scope the software was developed for (e.g., microgrid, Germany, Europe).
Regions covered by the model. Leave this blank if the model and data are not limited to a specific region. Examples include: USA, Canada, Germany, western Europe.
Supported voltage level of the software.
Information on an optimization included in the software.
A review of the software.
Information on the tests of the software.
Information on validations done for the software. Validation refers to whether the software produces results that correspond to real-world properties.
Typical minimal hardware which is required to run the software.
Typical execution time of the software.
Processor architecture required to run the application (e.g. IA64).
Minimum memory requirements.
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Processor requirements of a software component

ERSmeta Description: Storage requirements (free space required).
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Memory requirements of a software

ERSmeta Description: What kind of realtime simulations are supported by the software?
Does the software support parallization?
Target programming enviroments to which the code applies. If applies to several versions, just the product name can be used.
Operating systems supported (Windows 7, OSX 10.6, Android 1.6).
SoftwareDescriptionOntology Description: Operating systems under which a software component can operate

ERSmeta Description: Required software dependencies.
Size of the application / package (e.g. 18MB). In the absence of a unit (MB, KB etc.), KB will be assumed.
The type and version number of the metadata.
The license of the provided metadata.

Indicates the party responsible for generating and publishing the current structured data markup, typically in cases where the structured data is derived automatically from existing published content but published on a different site. For example, student projects and open data initiatives often re-publish existing content with more explicitly structured metadata. The sdPublisher property helps make such practices more explicit.
